body: I think since 4d040c71d7e which combined several different `connection` things into one single function, which does not accommodate for multiple ones passed by the application...

> I think since [4d040c7](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/4d040c71d7e611a0e5e9114c81eb6469a02090ea) which combined several different `connection` things into one single function, which does not accommodate for multiple ones passed by the application...

Yes, the code around https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/4d040c71d7e611a0e5e9114c81eb6469a02090ea#diff-14c8235d370910f1781de1a00ed1957ec948e84e88fdc52db87bd4eb7c7167ffR2640 looks suspicious.

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/374c23c617322ecd76794d058461f69b8abbef0e/lib/http.c#L2638-L2652
curl should probably merge the two (or more) provided ones into a single outgoing one, with comma separated values. To make it work correctly with any possibly internally added ones.

issue.title: http: combine multiple Connection headers into one

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
The proposed fix collects all connection header values, and combines them into a single header with comma separated values.

Test results show:
- Single header: Connection: keep-alive
- Two headers: Connection: keep-alive, close
- Three headers: Connection: keep-alive, close, upgrade

Fixes #18662
Reported-by: Karlson2k on github

body:
> curl should probably merge the two (or more) provided ones into a single outgoing one, with comma separated values. To make it work correctly with any possibly internally added ones.

Formally it would be almost equivalent, especially for HTTP/2 and HTTP/3.
However, HTTP/1.x servers **may** handle combined and separate headers differently. Previously, it was possible with curl to produce both kinds of requests: with combined and with separate headers. If you force combining headers always, then formally curl/libcurl will perform requests, but will not follow precisely what is user asked for.
In short: an average user most probably will not notice any difference, while for advanced uses it may be less flexible than before.

> curl should probably merge the two (or more) provided ones into a single outgoing one, with comma separated values. To make it work correctly with any possibly internally added ones.

I would suggest to combine automatic internally added headers with the first "Connection: " header, while handle other "Connection: " headers in a standard way.
This would provide a maximum compatibility: will work correctly with servers handling only the first/one connection header (the user have to use a single header even if several values are used) and give ability to produce requests with several "Connection: " headers if some server processes it differently.

issue.title: handle user-defined connection headers

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
When there is more than one user-supplied 'Connection: ' header, add values that curl needs internally to the first one and emit all subsequent ones thereafter.

Add test 1617 to verify.

refs #18662

body: I implemented that in #18686. Feedback appreciated.

The fix #18686 looks better.

@bagder Unrelated: may be it's time to introduce a proper API for custom headers?
Initial version with complete headers strings was nice when it was used directly: just throw all string with CRLF termination. But now, with HTTP/2 and HTTP/3, custom processing for HTTP/1.x, may be it would be better to redesign API for custom headers with separate strings for the name of the each "field" and the value of the each "field".
Internal handling will be simplified and streamlined. For applications it would be easier to use the new form too.
